title: How to Season Baked Salmon

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 400 °F (204 °C).
steps.description: If your oven is electric, it will likely require about 10 to 15 minutes to preheat. On the other hand, gas ovens take between 5 to 10 minutes to preheat. Position the oven rack into the center and then turn your oven to 400 °F (204 °C). If you're using a gas oven and smell gas, turn the oven off immediately in case it's a gas leak.

steps.headline: Mince 3 tablespoons (45 grams) of garlic.
steps.description: Start by separating the garlic piece into individual heads using your fingers. Place a clove under the blade of a chef's knife and whack the wide part of your blade with the palm of your hand. Remove the peel and then cut the thick end off the clove. Rock the knife up and down over the clove with your dominant hand on the handle and your non-dominant on top of the blade to keep it steady. Use a digital kitchen scale to weigh out your garlic cloves prior to cutting them.

steps.headline: Sprinkle both sides of your salmon fillets with salt and pepper.
steps.description: Start by wiping both sides of the salmon with paper towels until they're dry. Now, sprinkle some salt and pepper on to taste. Sprinkle a little bit at a time to avoid over-seasoning. Finish by cutting deep slits about 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart onto your salmon to help the seasoning flavor reach the inside of the meat. If you add too much salt and pepper, wipe it off with your paper towel.

steps.headline: Heat a mixture of butter, minced garlic, paprika, onion powder, cayenne pepper, and parsley.
steps.description: Mix your 4 tablespoons (56.7 grams) of unsalted butter, 3 teaspoons (14.3 grams) of minced garlic, 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of paprika, 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of onion powder, 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of cayenne pepper, and 3 tablespoons (45 grams) of fresh parsley into a saucepan. Heat it using an element on low-medium for about 5 minutes and stir it at the 1 minute mark. If your oven element requires exact temperature, set it to 250 to 324 °F (121 to 162 °C).

steps.headline: Brush your seasoning mixture over both sides of the salmon.
steps.description: Dip a cooking brush into the seasoning mixture generously. Brush your salmon fillets on each side and take care to cover every inch. If you prefer stronger seasoning, apply generously.

steps.headline: Bake your salmon at 400 °F (204 °C) for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Lightly spray the top of a baking sheet with cooking spray or pour a rough coating of oil over it. Place your salmon onto a baking sheet lined with baking paper or foil. Place your baking sheet onto the center oven rack. Remember that thicker cuts of salmon might take between 15 to 20 minutes to cook. Check your salmon by poking the thickest part with a fork—if it flakes easily, it's done.

steps.headline: Take your salmon out of the oven and enjoy!
steps.description: Serve you seasoned salmon with some lemon slices and Brussels sprouts for a tasty combination. If you prefer salmon with some more kick, sprinkle some additional paprika to taste. Store your salmon in the fridge for up to 3 days and in the freezer for 6 to 9 months.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 450 °F (232 °C).
steps.description: Before you do anything, place an oven rack into the middle slot. When it comes to preheating, gas ovens take about 5 to 10 minutes while electrical ovens take about 10 to 15 minutes. For the most accuracy, use an oven thermometer instead of waiting for your oven to beep—often your oven provides inaccurate measurements. Keep your windows open if you're using a gas oven and turn the oven off immediately if you smell gas.

steps.headline: Arrange your salmon fillets in a shallow baking dish.
steps.description: Spray the bottom of the dish with non-stick cooking spray. Afterward, place as many fillets as you can, leaving about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) between each. Finally, wrap a piece of aluminum foil over the dish to speed up the cooking time and retain moisture. Be sure to use an ovenproof cooking dish.

steps.headline: Mix your seasoning ingredients into a bowl.
steps.description: Start by adding 1 tablespoon (14 mL) of cider vinegar, 1 tablespoon (14 mL) of Worcestershire sauce, and 1 tablespoon (14 mL) of lemon juice. Afterward, add 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of salt, 1/8 teaspoon (0.625 grams) of black pepper, and 1 teaspoon (4.92 mL) of prepared mustard. Finally, add your 1/2 cup (110 grams) of melted unsalted butter. Add 1/4 teaspoon (1.25 grams) of paprika (optional) and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 grams} of dried parsley to give your sauce a bit more bite.

steps.headline: Pour half of your seasoning mixture over the fish.
steps.description: Gently pour the seasoning over the fish, taking care to move the bowl a steady motion back and forth over each piece of fish. Take care to pour an even amount of the mixture over the salmon. If there are some uneven regions, use a cooking brush to smooth them out. Cut slits into the fish approximately 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart before or after adding your seasoning to help it soak into the fish.

steps.headline: Bake your salmon at 450 °F (232 °C) for 20 minutes and bast it.
steps.description: Place your salmon onto the middle oven rack and bake it for 20 minutes. Every 5 minutes, remove the dish from the oven, apply your seasoning mixture to the salmon pieces, and place them back in the oven. This is called basting—it keeps the salmon moist with continuous seasoning application. Make sure you use all of your seasoning by the end of baking. Check your salmon by poking the thickest part with a fork—if it flakes easily, it's done!

steps.headline: Remove your salmon from the oven and enjoy!
steps.description: Serve your seasoned salmon with lemon and dried parsley if you'd like. If you want a bit of a kick, sprinkle about 1/4 teaspoon (1.25 grams) of paprika over it. Store your salmon in the refrigerator for up to 3 days or in the freezer for between 6 to 9 months.

text: Baking Garlic-Buttered Salmon Preheat your oven to 400 °F (204 °C). If your oven is electric, it will likely require about 10 to 15 minutes to preheat. On the other hand, gas ovens take between 5 to 10 minutes to preheat. Position the oven rack into the center and then turn your oven to 400 °F (204 °C). If you're using a gas oven and smell gas, turn the oven off immediately in case it's a gas leak. Mince 3 tablespoons (45 grams) of garlic. Start by separating the garlic piece into individual heads using your fingers. Place a clove under the blade of a chef's knife and whack the wide part of your blade with the palm of your hand. Remove the peel and then cut the thick end off the clove. Rock the knife up and down over the clove with your dominant hand on the handle and your non-dominant on top of the blade to keep it steady. Use a digital kitchen scale to weigh out your garlic cloves prior to cutting them. Sprinkle both sides of your salmon fillets with salt and pepper. Start by wiping both sides of the salmon with paper towels until they're dry. Now, sprinkle some salt and pepper on to taste. Sprinkle a little bit at a time to avoid over-seasoning. Finish by cutting deep slits about 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart onto your salmon to help the seasoning flavor reach the inside of the meat. If you add too much salt and pepper, wipe it off with your paper towel. Heat a mixture of butter, minced garlic, paprika, onion powder, cayenne pepper, and parsley. Mix your 4 tablespoons (56.7 grams) of unsalted butter, 3 teaspoons (14.3 grams) of minced garlic, 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of paprika, 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of onion powder, 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of cayenne pepper, and 3 tablespoons (45 grams) of fresh parsley into a saucepan. Heat it using an element on low-medium for about 5 minutes and stir it at the 1 minute mark. If your oven element requires exact temperature, set it to 250 to 324 °F (121 to 162 °C). Brush your seasoning mixture over both sides of the salmon. Dip a cooking brush into the seasoning mixture generously. Brush your salmon fillets on each side and take care to cover every inch. If you prefer stronger seasoning, apply generously. Bake your salmon at 400 °F (204 °C) for 10 to 15 minutes. Lightly spray the top of a baking sheet with cooking spray or pour a rough coating of oil over it. Place your salmon onto a baking sheet lined with baking paper or foil. Place your baking sheet onto the center oven rack. Remember that thicker cuts of salmon might take between 15 to 20 minutes to cook. Check your salmon by poking the thickest part with a fork—if it flakes easily, it's done. Take your salmon out of the oven and enjoy! Serve you seasoned salmon with some lemon slices and Brussels sprouts for a tasty combination. If you prefer salmon with some more kick, sprinkle some additional paprika to taste. Store your salmon in the fridge for up to 3 days and in the freezer for 6 to 9 months. Making Tangy Mustard Salmon Preheat your oven to 450 °F (232 °C). Before you do anything, place an oven rack into the middle slot. When it comes to preheating, gas ovens take about 5 to 10 minutes while electrical ovens take about 10 to 15 minutes. For the most accuracy, use an oven thermometer instead of waiting for your oven to beep—often your oven provides inaccurate measurements. Keep your windows open if you're using a gas oven and turn the oven off immediately if you smell gas. Arrange your salmon fillets in a shallow baking dish. Spray the bottom of the dish with non-stick cooking spray. Afterward, place as many fillets as you can, leaving about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) between each. Finally, wrap a piece of aluminum foil over the dish to speed up the cooking time and retain moisture. Be sure to use an ovenproof cooking dish. Mix your seasoning ingredients into a bowl. Start by adding 1 tablespoon (14 mL) of cider vinegar, 1 tablespoon (14 mL) of Worcestershire sauce, and 1 tablespoon (14 mL) of lemon juice. Afterward, add 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of salt, 1/8 teaspoon (0.625 grams) of black pepper, and 1 teaspoon (4.92 mL) of prepared mustard. Finally, add your 1/2 cup (110 grams) of melted unsalted butter. Add 1/4 teaspoon (1.25 grams) of paprika (optional) and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 grams} of dried parsley to give your sauce a bit more bite. Pour half of your seasoning mixture over the fish. Gently pour the seasoning over the fish, taking care to move the bowl a steady motion back and forth over each piece of fish. Take care to pour an even amount of the mixture over the salmon. If there are some uneven regions, use a cooking brush to smooth them out. Cut slits into the fish approximately 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart before or after adding your seasoning to help it soak into the fish. Bake your salmon at 450 °F (232 °C) for 20 minutes and bast it. Place your salmon onto the middle oven rack and bake it for 20 minutes. Every 5 minutes, remove the dish from the oven, apply your seasoning mixture to the salmon pieces, and place them back in the oven. This is called basting—it keeps the salmon moist with continuous seasoning application. Make sure you use all of your seasoning by the end of baking. Check your salmon by poking the thickest part with a fork—if it flakes easily, it's done! Remove your salmon from the oven and enjoy! Serve your seasoned salmon with lemon and dried parsley if you'd like. If you want a bit of a kick, sprinkle about 1/4 teaspoon (1.25 grams) of paprika over it. Store your salmon in the refrigerator for up to 3 days or in the freezer for between 6 to 9 months.

If your oven is electric, it will likely require about 10 to 15 minutes to preheat.
On the other hand, gas ovens take between 5 to 10 minutes to preheat.
Position the oven rack into the center and then turn your oven to 400 °F (204 °C).
If you're using a gas oven and smell gas, turn the oven off immediately in case it's a gas leak.
Mince 3 tablespoons (45 grams) of garlic.
Start by separating the garlic piece into individual heads using your fingers.
Place a clove under the blade of a chef's knife and whack the wide part of your blade with the palm of your hand.
Remove the peel and then cut the thick end off the clove.

Use a digital kitchen scale to weigh out your garlic cloves prior to cutting them.

Mix your 4 tablespoons (56.7 grams) of unsalted butter, 3 teaspoons (14.3 grams) of minced garlic, 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of paprika, 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of onion powder, 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of cayenne pepper, and 3 tablespoons (45 grams) of fresh parsley into a saucepan.
Heat it using an element on low-medium for about 5 minutes and stir it at the 1 minute mark.
If your oven element requires exact temperature, set it to 250 to 324 °F (121 to 162 °C).
Brush your seasoning mixture over both sides of the salmon.
Dip a cooking brush into the seasoning mixture generously.
Brush your salmon fillets on each side and take care to cover every inch.

Bake your salmon at 400 °F (204 °C) for 10 to 15 minutes.
Lightly spray the top of a baking sheet with cooking spray or pour a rough coating of oil over it.
Place your salmon onto a baking sheet lined with baking paper or foil.
Place your baking sheet onto the center oven rack.
Remember that thicker cuts of salmon might take between 15 to 20 minutes to cook.
Check your salmon by poking the thickest part with a fork—if it flakes easily, it's done.

If you prefer salmon with some more kick, sprinkle some additional paprika to taste.
Store your salmon in the fridge for up to 3 days and in the freezer for 6 to 9 months.
Making Tangy Mustard Salmon Preheat your oven to 450 °F (232 °C).
Before you do anything, place an oven rack into the middle slot.
When it comes to preheating, gas ovens take about 5 to 10 minutes while electrical ovens take about 10 to 15 minutes.
For the most accuracy, use an oven thermometer instead of waiting for your oven to beep—often your oven provides inaccurate measurements.
Keep your windows open if you're using a gas oven and turn the oven off immediately if you smell gas.
Arrange your salmon fillets in a shallow baking dish.
Spray the bottom of the dish with non-stick cooking spray.
Afterward, place as many fillets as you can, leaving about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) between each.
Finally, wrap a piece of aluminum foil over the dish to speed up the cooking time and retain moisture.
Be sure to use an ovenproof cooking dish.
Mix your seasoning ingredients into a bowl.
Start by adding 1 tablespoon (14 mL) of cider vinegar, 1 tablespoon (14 mL) of Worcestershire sauce, and 1 tablespoon (14 mL) of lemon juice.
Afterward, add 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of salt, 1/8 teaspoon (0.625 grams) of black pepper, and 1 teaspoon (4.92 mL) of prepared mustard.
Finally, add your 1/2 cup (110 grams) of melted unsalted butter.
Add 1/4 teaspoon (1.25 grams) of paprika (optional) and 1/2 teaspoon (2.5 grams} of dried parsley to give your sauce a bit more bite.
Pour half of your seasoning mixture over the fish.
Gently pour the seasoning over the fish, taking care to move the bowl a steady motion back and forth over each piece of fish.
Take care to pour an even amount of the mixture over the salmon.
If there are some uneven regions, use a cooking brush to smooth them out.
Cut slits into the fish approximately 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart before or after adding your seasoning to help it soak into the fish.
Bake your salmon at 450 °F (232 °C) for 20 minutes and bast it.
Place your salmon onto the middle oven rack and bake it for 20 minutes.
Every 5 minutes, remove the dish from the oven, apply your seasoning mixture to the salmon pieces, and place them back in the oven.
This is called basting—it keeps the salmon moist with continuous seasoning application.
Make sure you use all of your seasoning by the end of baking.
Check your salmon by poking the thickest part with a fork—if it flakes easily, it's done!
Remove your salmon from the oven and enjoy!
Serve your seasoned salmon with lemon and dried parsley if you'd like.
If you want a bit of a kick, sprinkle about 1/4 teaspoon (1.25 grams) of paprika over it.
Store your salmon in the refrigerator for up to 3 days or in the freezer for between 6 to 9 months.
